turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Tommy E.L.Williams, petitioner, versus City of Oklahoma, et al.

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Mr. Justice -- Chief Justice may it please the Court.

Yesterday afternoon, inquiry was made I believe by Justice White relative to the significance of some language in the trial court's order pertaining to the inability of the defendant or his counsel to prepare a transcript from memory.

The reason for this is the courts in Oklahoma have set this as one of the prerequisites for furnishing a free case-made and we think that it's significant for the reason that by implication it indicate that for this requirement to have any relevance, it must mean that if the defendant or his counsel could prepare a transcript that the court would consider it.
We'd like to further remind the Court that part of this record has already been transcribed.

That three of the witnesses that petitioner maintains or material had -- their testimony has already been prepared in narrative form, that the only testimony needed were the three witnesses that testified in behalf of the city and the defendant and we believe that this could be prepared in narrative form and we think that the courts, that the appellate court below would consider it in that fashion.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Ratcliffe, as I read the opinion of the Court of Criminal Appeals, they didn't touch this at all.

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: No sir, they did not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was it argued to them?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: I wasn't in that proceeding in that time and I don't know but it did not go to that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, don't you think if there was a procedure in the Court of Criminal Appeals, would you suggest that they would have mentioned in their opinion?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, I'd like to think that they did.
They would have but if the question was not put to them I just don't know whether they would consider it or not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They went on the merits and said that simply because this was an ordinance and not statute, you didn't get it, period.

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Yes.
That in as much of this was a violation of municipal ordinance that there was no statutory authority for it --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And if it had been the statute and the man had been given 90 days, there would have been?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: The state law authorizes the furnishing of case-mades in those cases that are tried in the county and the District Courts.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that's the only point that they decided.

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Yes.
However, we can --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you support that?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you support that?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, I believe that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's the magic difference between the violation of an ordinance -- well let me first ask, does he go to the same jail?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He goes to a city jail?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But he has served 90 days?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And if he goes to the city jail and served 90 days and he's a pauper, no appeal?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If he's sentenced by a state statute, he goes to the state jail for 90 days, he gets a record?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you said that's alright?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, I say that in this particular case, that there's been no need or necessity shown that he have a reporter's stenographic copy of the record, that this was a case that was tried in less than a day, that it was not particularly complicated case, that there were just four witnesses, that this testimony could have been prepared in narrative form and submitted to the court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well would the -- would you have answered that in the brief if they have prepared a narrative out of their mind, would you have answered it?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, I think we've been given opportunity to approve it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean when the argument came up in the Court of Criminal Appeals, would you have had the transcript to work on?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: If we have ordered one, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the other side wouldn't?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, no.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you don't see anything wrong with that?

turn.speaker: giles_k_ratcliffe
turn.label: Mr. Giles K. Ratcliffe
turn.text: Well, I don't know why there would be any necessity for us to have a transcript if we could stipulate and agree and approve on the narrative form statement of the issues.
And as I say, I can't cite you any cases where Oklahoma has held that they would consider it this way but by implication, I think that it's there, that it could be.
Thank you, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
